13.text: By 1861 the British Empire was a global economic force.

19.text: Despite this, the common man had little opportunity to save.

25.text: Two men developed a plan of national importance and significance

29.text: Charles Sikes, a Huddersfield banker, proposed the establishment of the Money Order Department

35.text: of the Post Office to manage savings throughout the country.

42.text: And George Chetwynd, a book-keeper in the Money Order Department, came up with the idea

47.text:
of the Depositor’s Book.
Their plan appealed to William Gladstone,

54.text:
then Chancellor of the Exchequer, who saw
the need for the working man to save for his

60.text:
future, and piloted the scheme into law.
His hope was for a savings bank ”within

67.text:
an hour’s walk of every working man’s
fireside”

72.text: When we launched as the Post Office Savings Bank, it was an immediate success.

77.text:
Even the great novelist, Charles Dickens,
approved.

81.text:
If this doesn’t make people save, nothing
will.

86.text: The bank continued to expand under careful management.

90.text: Between 1863 and 1911, deposits rose from £3 million to £176 million,

99.text:
creating the need for purpose built offices,
populated by a thriving community of employees.

112.text:
Over the last century, we’ve continued to
flourish, supporting savers through war and peace.

119.text: To encourage savings at a time of post-war

122.text: regeneration, in 1956 we introduced Premium Savings Bonds to great success.

131.text: We’ve always maintained our relevance, whatever challenges the economy has faced.

136.text:
Why?
Because we were established to help the ordinary

139.text: person with safe, secure and simple saving.

146.text:
Whatever the challenges, we’ll carry on evolving and thriving. We’re here for you
today and tomorrow.

156.text: Safe, secure and surprisingly simple since 1861.
